review: Roku does far more than Chromecast, so I bought it solely for the beta function of the Chromecast tab on the Chrome browser which would allow you to put whatever you were watching on your laptop, etc. on your television screen.  It's very much a work in progress unfortunately.  The video on the computer was fine, but when going through Chromecast was jerky and would start and stop; voice and video were out of sync.  This seems to be a common complaint.  This could be a killer device, but not at the moment.  At $35 with Amazon Prime shipping it was worth a try out.  At this point, if you don't have it, don't bother.

review: At $35, you get just about 1/3 the usefulness of its competitors. The exception is tabcasting; a good idea, but it's not there yet: video and audio don't sync up if you cast a page like Hulu, and for just regular browsing, you don't get to see the pointer.However, casting Netflix from my phone was flawless and hi-res.I feel it will get better with time and updates. It's not there yet, but it's a promising start (for $35).
